author: .vbuterin
content: hmm I don't see how any oslution in that category would work

author: .vbuterin
content: eventually there is some 20 byte address that is outputted by whatever procedure generates addresses

author: .vbuterin
content: And so you can use a black box collision finding algorithm to find (i) parameters for that procedure and (ii) parameters for the "make a wallet I control" procedure, that both output the same address

author: .vbuterin
content: If we want to do ASE, I think my view at this point is that what we should do is make EOF 32-byte-address from day one, and give solidity a flag that it treats `Address` as a 32-byte type when compiling to EOF code. EOF would be able to interact with pre-EOF, but not the other way around, and we would basically have a 10-year-old awkward py2/py3-style transition, at the end up which almost everything, including dapps and tokens, is switched over to 32 byte

author: .vbuterin
content: in the meantime, we'd need every ERC20 to have some kind of wrapper contract for EOF addresses to hold it

author: sky.cactus
content: It seems unlikely that USDC will ever migrate.  Tornado Cash cannot migrate.  Any actually immutable app won't be able to migrate.

author: sky.cactus
content: Unless core devs are willing to do irregular state changes to migrate all immutable contracts over, but this will likely break all UIs for those apps.

author: .vbuterin
content: then EOF users would have to interact with those apps through some kind of enshrined proxy account. Could even be sequentially assigned <:crazycry:932693133546889216>

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Is adddress space extension/contraction really the only solution for state expiry? If it's just about adding some flags per account, why not store them in a separate tree?

author: sky.cactus
content: I personally think it is the only solution, and back when I was involved in discussions we did try to find alternatives.  I forget the details now, but it would be nice to find other options.

author: sky.cactus
content: One issue is that 20 bytes isn't collision resistant for too much longer.  Even if we ignore the need to do ASE for state expiry, we still need to solve it for collision reasons.
